newsitem.title: UKRAINE: Russia, Ukraine leaders to meet in Moscow.
newsitem.headline: Russia, Ukraine leaders to meet in Moscow.

text.p: Ukrainian President Leonid Kuchma flies to Moscow on Thursday to meet President Boris Yeltsin for talks overshadowed by a Russian parliament vote to freeze division of the disputed Black Sea fleet.
Deputies in Russia's State Duma lower house voted overwhelmingly on Wednesday to halt division between Russia and Ukraine of the 600-vessel fleet, a vestige of the former Soviet Union.

They have argued that the fleet, created more than 200 years ago as a single highly-integrated structure, would not survive the split and the two countries would be left without a naval force in the Black Sea.
Yeltsin's representative in the Duma, Alexander Kotenkov, made clear the vote had not been coordinated with the president, who is preparing for heart surgery.
The vote is likely to upset already uneasy relations between the two Slav former Soviet states.
Kuchma reacted angrily, saying the vote could lead to "a worsening in relations between the Ukrainian and Russian people" -- and not just between two legislatures.
His spokesman Dmytro Markov suggested it would not have a negative effect on the meeting with the Russian leader, saying: "It will be a meeting between friends."
Kuchma said a firm deal had been reached on Tuesday by members of a joint commission which foresaw Moscow paying rent to keep ships at the Crimean port of Sevastopol, in Ukraine.
"There is a practical understanding, there are no differences," Kuchma was quoted as saying by Interfax-Ukraine news agency.
Ukrainian officials also say negotiating teams have made considerable progress on the issue.
But Russia's Itar-Tass news agency quoted a source in Yeltsin's administration as saying the Russian leader did not share such optimism.
Broad accords have already been signed dividing the fleet but no decision has been reached on a share-out of bases and the future of its headquarters at Sevastopol.

Markov said "principal and important" issues could be raised by Kuchma and Yeltsin but that the full spectrum of bilateral questions would be addressed at a meeting with Russian Prime Minister Viktor Chernomyrdin.
Before falling ill in June, Yeltsin had postponed six trips to Kiev in 20 months to sign a friendship treaty.
Ukrainian Foreign Minister Hennady Udovenko said in Washington on Tuesday that a deal could be signed next month.
In a sign that Kiev could be softening its position on the fleet, three top Ukrainian navy officials who oppose giving in to Russia on the issue resigned.

"The defence minister of Ukraine today signed a document accepting the resignation of three top navy officials, including the head of the navy, Volodymyr Bezkorovainy," said Defence Ministry spokesman Igor Melnichuk.
Officially, Bezkorovainy and his deputy Alexei Ryzhenko have resigned for health reasons, while chief-of-staff Nikolai Kostrov has gone to another post.
But the move was bound to be interpreted as a sign Kiev could be ready to compromise on the issue of where to put its post-Soviet share of the fleet of a few dozen vessels.
